title: September tube strikes: Dates, times and services affected across London
description: Commuters face heavy disruption on their journeys to work after unions announced strikes on the London Underground.
content:
Commuters face heavy disruption on their journeys to work after unions announced strikes on the London Underground.

The scale of the disruption means it will not just affect Tube travellers, as passengers are forced to find alternative ways to get to work.

Barring an eleventh-hour delay, it will be the first time this year that Underground workers have walked out.

Here is everything you need to know about the impending disruption.

When are the Tube strikes?

The National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers (RMT) has announced rolling strikes, which are expected to hit Tube services from Sunday Sept 7 to Thursday Sept 11.

Transport for London (TfL) said the whole of the network on the London Underground will be “severely disrupted” from Sept 7 to Sept 11.

Little to no service is expected on those dates. There will be no services at all before 8am.

In a separate dispute, there will be no services on the Docklands Light Railway (DLR) on Tuesday Sept 9 or Thursday Sept 11.

In a move that will have less impact on passengers, Ruislip depot operational managers will go on strike from 6pm on Friday Sept 5 and 5.59pm on Saturday Sept 6.

Union members are walking out in a dispute over pay and conditions, including a demand for a 32-hour working week.

The RMT said management had “refused to engage seriously with union demands”.

It said it had raised concerns on “pay, fatigue management, extreme shift patterns and a reduction in the working week”.

The union said management had also failed to honour previous agreements with staff.

It said: “Management’s dismissive approach has fuelled widespread anger and distrust among the workforce, who voted in overwhelming numbers to take strike action.”

The DLR dispute is also over pay and conditions.

According to TfL: “Since the ballot was undertaken, London Underground has offered a 3.4pc pay increase in the ongoing pay discussions.

“Members of the RMT at London Underground have not had a say on the final pay offer, with the 3.4pc pay increase a figure in line with offers accepted by RMT in recent pay discussions across the rail industry.”

Claire Mann, TfL’s chief operating officer, said: “We are disappointed that the RMT union has announced strike action.

“We regularly meet with our trade unions to discuss any concerns that they may have, and we recently met with the RMT to discuss some specific points ...

“We welcome further engagement with our unions about fatigue and rostering across London Underground, but a reduction in the contractual 35-hour working week is neither practical nor affordable.”
summary: The National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers (RMT) has announced rolling strikes on the London Underground, expected to occur from Sunday Sept 7 to Thursday Sept 11. This will be the first time this year that Underground workers have walked out. Transport for London (TfL) has warned that the whole network will be severely disrupted, with little to no service expected on these dates. In a separate dispute, Ruislip depot operational managers will strike from 6pm on Friday to 5.59pm on Saturday Sept 6. The RMT has criticised management for failing to honour previous agreements with staff, and has offered a 3.4pc pay increase in ongoing pay discussions.
shortSummary: London Underground is facing severe disruption due to strikes by RMT union members over pay and conditions, with major disruption expected from September 7-11.
argos_summary: London Underground workers announced rolling strikes from September 7‑11, causing severe disruption across the network, with no services before 8 am and additional DLR strikes on September 9 and 11. The action stems from pay and working‑conditions disputes, including a demand for a 32‑hour week, after management offered a 3.4 % pay rise. TfL says the strike will force commuters to find alternative routes.
